solution.text:
The zero of \(_{j}_+_{k}_x\,\) is \(_{{Fraction (-j,k)}}_\).
Substituting zero of \(g(x)\,\) in \(p(x)\,\), we get,
\(p(_{{Fraction (-j,k)}}_)=(_{j}_ \times (_{{Fraction (-j,k)}}_)^3) + (_{k}_ \times (_{{Fraction (-j,k)}}_)^2)\)
\(\Rightarrow p(_{{Fraction (-j,k)}}_)=_{{j*Fraction(-j,k)*Fraction(-j,k)*Fraction(-j,k)}}_+(_{{k*Fraction(-j,k)*Fraction(-j,k)}}_)\)
\(\Rightarrow p(_{{Fraction(-j,k)}}_)=_{{j*Fraction(-j,k)*Fraction(-j,k)*Fraction(-j,k)-k*Fraction(-j,k)*Fraction(-j,k)}}_\)
The remainder when \(p(x)\) is divided by \(g(x)\) is \(_{{j*Fraction(-j,k)*Fraction(-j,k)*Fraction(-j,k)-k*Fraction(-j,k)*Fraction(-j,k)}}_\)
Therefore, \(_{j}_+_{k}_x\,\) is not a factor of \(_{j}_x^3+_{k}_x^2\).

content.text: Examine whether \(_{j}_+_{k}_x\,\) is a factor of \(_{j}_x^3+_{k}_x^2\).
